skill.name: docstring
skill.description: Write docstrings for PyTorch functions and methods following PyTorch conventions. Use when writing or updating docstrings in PyTorch code.
skill.summary: Generate PyTorch-compliant docstrings using Sphinx/reStructuredText format with proper parameter documentation and examples.

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only markdown documentation with guidelines for writing PyTorch docstrings. No executable code, scripts, network calls, file system access, or external command execution. Pure prompt-based skill with zero risk.

content.value_statement: Writing consistent, complete docstrings for PyTorch functions takes time and attention to detail. This skill provides comprehensive guidelines for generating Sphinx/reStructuredText-formatted docstrings with proper parameter types, cross-references, mathematical formulas, and executable examples.
actual_capabilities: Generate PyTorch docstrings in Sphinx/reStructuredText format
Document function parameters with proper type annotations
Add cross-references to related PyTorch classes and functions
Include mathematical formulas using LaTeX notation
Create notes and warnings for important caveats
limitations: Designed specifically for PyTorch project conventions, not general Python
Does not execute or test docstrings for correctness
Does not access existing codebase documentation
Does not generate API reference websites

use_cases.title: Add documentation to new functions

prompt_templates.prompt: Write a PyTorch docstring for this function using the docstring skill guidelines: def my_function(input: Tensor, scale: float = 1.0) -> Tensor

prompt_templates.title: C-Bound Function

best_practices: Always use raw strings (r""") to avoid LaTeX backslash escaping issues
Include a complete function signature on the first line with all parameters and default values
Add executable Python examples using the >>> syntax to verify correctness
Use Sphinx cross-references (:class:, :func:, :meth:) to link related PyTorch components
anti_patterns: Using regular strings instead of raw strings causes issues with mathematical backslashes
Missing type annotations in Args section makes documentation incomplete
Omitting examples reduces usability and makes testing documentation harder
Forgetting the ~ prefix in cross-references shows full qualified names instead of short names

faq.question: Does this skill work for general Python projects?
faq.answer: No, this skill follows PyTorch-specific conventions including Sphinx formatting and internal documentation patterns.

faq.question: What docstring formats are supported?
faq.answer: PyTorch uses Sphinx/reStructuredText format with specific patterns for Args, Returns, Examples, and cross-references.

faq.question: Can I use this for NumPy-style docstrings?
faq.answer: No, NumPy and Google docstring styles are different. PyTorch requires Sphinx/reStructuredText format.

faq.question: Is the generated documentation automatically tested?
faq.answer: No, this skill generates the docstring text. You should add executable examples that can be verified separately.

faq.question: Does this skill access my code files?
faq.answer: No, this is a prompt-based skill. You provide the function signature and it generates documentation text.

faq.question: How is this different from auto-doc tools like Sphinx autodoc?
faq.answer: This skill writes the actual docstring content following PyTorch conventions, while autodoc extracts existing docstrings.
